5.	Five-Year Accident History

Mobils facility has had no accidents that meet the criteria for the Five-Year Accident History. 

6.	Emergency Response Program Information

Mobil is a member of the Petal Dome Mutual Aid (PDMA) group.  Mobil also has a national and 
regional response team with members trained to handle emergencies. 

The PDMA has an emergency response plan which details procedures for accidental releases and 
includes notification of the Forrest County LEPC and other local authorities.  We maintain an 
open door policy with local emergency response organizations to help ensure maximum 
understanding and cooperation during an emergency.

7.	Planned Changes to Improve Safety

Mobils facility personnel continually strive to improve all aspects of our safety programs to 
protect our workers and the public.

Mobil Oil Corporation
Hattiesburg LPG Storage Facility
Risk Management Plan (RMP)
Executive Summary

1.	Accidental Release Prevention and Response Policies

The Mobil Oil Corporation, Hattiesburg LPG Storage Facility (Mobil), in Petal, Mississippi is a 
liquified petroleum gas storage facility.  The gases stored are propane and butane.  The facility 
utilizes certain safety precautions to prevent unnecessary on-site human exposure and to 
minimize the potential for any offsite exposure.  These safety precautions include: 

- Effectively managing our process operations;
- Investing in the latest process safety technologies;
- Training and retraining our personnel;
- Reviewing our processes for hazards on a continuous basis;
- Ensuring safety is considered in process design, installation, operations and maintenance.

The facility maintains a policy to be a good business partner; a safe and conscientious neighbor; 
and to operate in compliance with all applicable laws and regulations. 

Mobil has a standing commitment to worker and public safety.  This is evidenced by our history 
of support and commitment to the community and our high environmental standards.  We are 
proud of our Safety and Environmental Programs and continually strive to be the best.

2.	Description of the Stationary Source and Regulated Substances

Mobils facility contains the RMP regulated flammable substances of propane and butane.

3.	Hazard Assessment Results

The RMP rule requires companies to develop chemical release scenarios that estimate the 
potential community impact from an accidental release.  These scenarios are useful for 
emergency planning in case of an accident.  There are two types of scenarios required by the 
EPA.  The worst-case scenario (WCS) is the release of the largest quantity of a regulated 
substance.  The alternative release scenario (ARS) allows industries to develop a more realistic 
planning scenario.

A release of propane is the WCS and ARS for flammable chemicals

at Mobils facility which 
result in offsite consequences.  The offsite impact is mitigated by our prevention programs listed 
in section one above. 

4.	General Accidental Release Prevention Program and Chemical-Specific Prevention 
Steps

Mobil has developed an Environmental, Health & Safety Management System (EHSMS) which 
delineates the responsibilities of each team member to help prevent major incidents and protect 
human health and the environment. 

Our terminal superintendent has the overall responsibility for ensuring that our facility operates 
in a safe and reliable manner.  However, all personnel ensure that safe work practices, equipment 
design specifications, and maintenance schedules are adhered to thereby reducing the probability 
of an incident at the facility.

Mobil has developed programs to comply with all environmental, health, and safety laws.  We 
take a systematic, proactive approach to preventing accidental releases.  Our process 
management systems address each of the essential features of successful accident prevention 
programs including:

- Process safety information 		- Pre-startup review
- Process hazard analysis 		- Compliance audits
- Operating procedures			- Incident investigation
- Training				- Employee participation
- Mechanical integrity			- Hot work permits
- Management of change 			- Contractor safety

Our risk management program uses these individual elements to prevent accidental chemical 
releases.  

We employ extensive mechanical integrity and preventive maintenance programs to ensure the 
integrity of our equipment and safety systems.  Our mechanical integrity program uses equipment 
surveillance and preventive maintenance activities to identify equipment that may be 
deteriorating and in need of repair or replacement, before failure occurs.  This program also 
specifies the repairs (or parts replacement) needed to return equipment to acceptable 
specifications.
